title: I’m 26 years old and going through a divorce and a home owner. Would I look like a loser moving back to my mom’s house with my daughter since I can’t afford to live on my own? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. You need help, if your mom lets you move in, that’s a good thing. Just make sure you don’t ‘expect’ your mom to babysit, or cook for you or your child. Your mom is not a maid either. Clean up after yourself and your baby immediately after you….whatever it is. Pay rent, give her something. I’m not saying pay half the mortgage, but if you plan on being there… she may not accept the cash but offer it to her anyway. If she won’t take it, buy her stuff. Good stuff. She still has bills to pay. Expect to pay for and go get your (and your childs) own food. I knew a man some 15 years ago. he was 50ish then. He had moved himself and his two kids into his mom and step dad’s house when the kids were about 3 and 4. He is still there. He pays for nothing. He would say he was going to the store and his mom would say “you need any money?”, he would go to her a get money. His mom went to work every day and he would sit on his ass and watch tv all day and all night. He would play his music loud and not wash a dish. He didn’t make his kids take out the trash or lift a finger in that house.( he didn’t, why should they) I dated him for 2 months. Wait we didn’t go anywhere or do anything. Anything. I went to work and came to his mom and dads. He wouldn’t even walk two houses to my house. That is a loser. the kids are grown now. I hope they dont still live there, but if they do, I would not blame them. Rent is expensive. Roommates are hard I imagine, but if you could find a guy with a child your child’s age - and same gender so they could share a bedroom, maybe - and you go half on rent and utilities. Best wishes

Absolutely not, you’ll look like a good father who prioritizes his daughter having a stable home over his own pride. These are hard times, and family is meant to be there for us when we need them. You are FAR from the only person who finds themselves unexpectedly back with their family after hard times. I know, because I did too. And I’m 35, and have no kids, so if you’re a loser, I don’t want to know what I am. I moved back after my own divorce, lay-off and the death of my best friend and roommate. I needed a safe haven. You should make sure that YOU aren’t the one calling yourself “loser.” It’s important for your daughter not to see you down on yourself, and also to understand that being an adult means sometimes things aren’t how we want or expected them to be, but we can still find our way through. One way you can make yourself feel better, while also providing a good example for your daughter, is by making sure you contribute to the household in whatever way you can, whether monetarily or with helping your mother around the house. I wouldn’t be surprised if your mother was happy to have her son and grand-daughter living in the house, especially if she also gets some help with cleaning, cooking, or whatever else. Try to look at this as a potentially healing, mutually beneficial situation for all of you, instead of seeing it as some sort of personal failure. As simple as that sounds, I’ve found that sometimes a small shift in perspective can really change how you feel about something. Wishing you and your family the best. You’ll get through this together. - Stacey
